name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: There, the community analogy lines up with co-ops and how they "compete" over how well they manage the building's assets. And a co-op is like a DAO. So, the value of metaverse projects will not only depend on creating cachet but also effective DAO governance.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: But there's another way to think about this that revives the land analogy: the idea of high-rise properties and strata title (think NYC buildings), which expands the supply of otherwise finite land .

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: That's not that novel from the way all cultural output  or IP (which is equally infinite at its fundamental level) is valued. The difference is the intensification of community leadership, rather than corporate marketing efforts, in that brand-building.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: That suggests that as the total amount of metaverse "land" tends toward infinity, intense competition to assert and protect the brand  will arise between different metaverse projects

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Presumably, that mean the value of your Otherside "land" is dependent on the Apecoin/BAYC project itself continuing to maintain its desirability, which in turns depends on the collective efforts of the Apecoin community to maintain its cachet and a sense of exclusivity

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Rather, scarcity is determined by the desirability and limited access to the project itself. The value of @yugalabs' Otherside offering was intrinsically linked to perceived value of the BAYC "brand." In that sense, it's akin to the value of limited edition Air Jordan.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: I think calling metaverse space "land" can be misleading. Of course, in its entirety, the offerings from  these projects are not scarce in the same sense that physical land is finite and scarce.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @MichaelHiles @jonst0kes @doctorow I used to really like @doctorow's work. As someone who covered the 2008 financial meltdown and devoured smart analyses such as his of how TBTF banks held the US public hostage, his two recent threads on crypto have been quite upsetting for me.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@MichaelHiles True that. 

But the generalization @jonst0kes is calling out comes from the other direction. @doctorow is suggesting coders don't understand finance (and then, ergo, DeFi is bunk - nice leap, huh?) when the reality is that coders now, more or less, OWN Wall St.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
This. 

A major, if not the biggest, cause of the 2008 crisis (of which Doctorow talks with total faux wisdom) is the fact that Wall St was recruiting as many CS grads as MIT could produce to create quant machines that would extract unreasonable rents from the market.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @thinkovation @mayazi No. Like a consensus system by which a network of users can collectively affirm that a particular digital signature is also a demonstration of legally enforceable rights. That's what needs to be built - something that ties NFTs/digital signatures to the pre-existing world of law.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi But I agree, the current ownership-based marketplace environment isn't particularly innovative in terms of business models. As I said, there are big pieces missing. Various people working on creating those pieces.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi What if we exchange "ownership" for "control." The issue, is who gets to define usage rights for a digital artifact? Whether we're talking about commercial rights or creative commons open usage, it should be the creator of the art/content/intellectual property conveyed within it

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @thinkovation @mayazi Not yet, no. All NFTs do now is to immutably tie a digital signature to a digital file. They don't establish ownership of that file. But in creating that link, they're a building block for a new, creator-centric model for defining and assigning rights.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @thinkovation @mayazi There's no meaningful way to express digital property rights in Web2. So internet platforms  - backed by lawyers with an exploitative DRM model - created a destructive system of surveillance capitalism. We desperately need to fix this. Web3 creates the framework for doing so.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi I think we're now building the substrate of digital ownership as a technical and social construct. We still need other elements to connect this new construct with existing constructs (e.g. NFT-based digital rights with law). Then the app layer (biz models) can arise.

name: Michael J. Casey

name: Michael J. Casey
Michael J. Casey
tweet: That's @WIRED's future. It's also @CoinDesk's and that of every other serious crypto media outlet.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Gideon says the essence of @WIRED's storytelling does not lie in the technologies per se but in the challenges that society faces. The task is to tell stories that focus on PEOPLE, on how human beings are using those technologies to tackle those challenges - for good or bad.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Similarly to the conclusion Gideon draws about WIRED's responsibility in covering technologies that enable profound change, crypto media outlets like ours must avoid the temptation to see the tech as inherently good or bad, as either a panacea for, or the root cause, of our ills.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: I've often used WIRED's history - as the publication that owned the story of the internet by recognizing before everyone else that it would change everything - as a reference point for CoinDesk in the era of blockchain, crypto and digital assets.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: I was pleased to see @glichfield open this excellent piece on @WIRED's future with a blockchain reference. As the most important media outlet of the crypto era, we at @CoinDesk face similar challenges grappling with a divisive good v. bad binary around technology...

https://t.co/FIrahlvDrI

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jallepap 💯 The biggest lesson from COVID, for me, is that linear thinking is a major human failure. We extrapolate from single anecdotes into overly confident conclusions about entire populations. Post-COVID educational priorities: teach people about systems and exponentiality.

name: Michael J. Casey
Michael J. Casey
tweet:
Uggh. 

Pro-vaxxers know 100% immunity isn't the point. 

Vaccine policy is about the math of contagion. About reducing likelihood, not absolutes. It's how we collectively reduce R0. 

The anti-vax line that "vaccines are imperfect, so why bother" is asinine beyond belief

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@Bradenjbrady Oh yeah. On that point, yes, we'll be feeling the impact of this for a decade, at least. But "interesting" is the best way to look at it. 

What incumbent models will die as a result? What new approaches to life and business will arise from out of this?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mikealfred Not black and white, Mike. Not from societal (systems) perspective. I think it's about managed exposure. Flatten the curve so our hospital system doesn't collapse. But if we spread it out, widespread contraction of a less severe variant (i.e. your "ride) may be the way forward

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Bradenjbrady "Decade" too pessimistic. Use revived fear to flatten the curve. A month of distancing to stop hospital flooding. We don't stop the virus but manageably spread out contraction of a less severe variant over time. Six months in, with Pfizer pill etc, we can start to live with it

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Noahpinion I think you're both wrong. Yes, it's clear now that boosters are vital for everyone, but surely we have an urgent obligation to simultaneously get the most exposed of all of us on their way to 1st, 2nd and eventually 3rd jabs.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller Anyway, this has been fun. It's way past my bedtime

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller But so we're clear: I consider myself of the left. Nothing terrifies me more than fascism. Believe it or not, holding that position is not antithetical to crypto.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller Yep. Socialists were tremendous at predicting the worst aspects of capitalism. But their state-based solutions proved unworkable in all but a few Nordic cases in the 20th century's pre-internet economy. They are now even more out of touch in the internet age.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller You can't look digital property rights from within the old 20th century capitalism-vs-socialism dichotomy. Neither side of that ideological divide could imagine the world of "surveillance capitalism" we now live in. What's at stake is human free will.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller Substitute the words "property rights" for "data rights" and see where that takes you. As in "this data output I generate to - through the creation of content and my interactions with others' content - is mine. In the digital age it is fundamental to my very humanity."

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller Yes, we need laws that treat FAANGs as monopolies. But we also need a model for how human beings can autonomously interact with each other within the borderless internet economy in which we spend much of our time.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller We need a decentralized governance framework to match the decentralized way in which digital power is already controlled by anonymous, geography-agnostic entities.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller Look at you and your certitude! "Only this. Only that." Try imagining a different paradigm. Again, did you read my column...?

If you'd read it you'd realize I'm a big advocate for antitrust laws. The problem is that much of the internet lives outside of jurisdictional reach.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller Again: a narrow framework. What if my definition of digital property rights has nothing to do with money or capitalism and instead is all about defining the rights of sovereign individuals in the digital age, so that can restore autonomy over our data and reassert out free will?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller Much like the 1st internet protocols in the early 90s, many problems must be resolved for NFTs to fulfill their potential. But to dismiss the breakthrough these building blocks represent is ignorant. For the 1st time, we can identify unique digital assets - a big fucking deal!

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller What we do with them is an open question. Do we turn them into a money-grabbing opportunity as is currently the high-profile use case that's getting your and other armchair analysts' attention or use them to build new a self-sovereign power base to challenge the FAANGs?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller Nope. They are what we choose to make of them. My view: NFTs are a badly needed building block for asserting property rights in the digital ages: over our content, our personal data, our identities. But they a just.a.building.block.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @yaketystax @marshall5912 @panekkkk @CoinDesk @matthewstoller "Obviously?" You're making my point about the mind trap of dominant paradigms. Why is it obvious? (Again, read my column?) Why assume the current, centralized governance model is a natural permanent state? It's only a couple of centuries old. And its flaws were made clear in 2008

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller You're analyzing the milieu around NFTs, not NFTs themselves - confusing the social phenomenon with the cryptographic innovation. You're not alone - crypto ppl overly emphasize the business built on NFTs, not their essential relevance. They make similarly sweeping generalizations

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller All NFTs do is to tie an uncensorable blockchain time-stamped record of ownership to a digital file of some description.  It says nothing about money or control (DRM) over that digital file. The money part refers to what people have chosen to do with this new recording system.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @marshall5912 @panekkkk @yaketystax @CoinDesk @matthewstoller It's depressing how both sides of this boring debate let their emotional reactions overwhelm rational analysis and default to simplistic stereotypes. Is this decentralized governance system a way out of our current socio-economic malaise or not? That's the only question.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jp_koning @GeorgeSelgin @CoinDesk I'd be happy if regulators chose to let KYC go. Greater financial inclusion; law enforcement compelled to focus on stopping crimes, not   money flows. But if SC issuers were also allowed to run sub-par reserves, eventually financial chaos would ensue. To me the choice is easy.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Gonzo_MM @GeorgeSelgin @Kiffmeister @jp_koning @CoinDesk Oh yes. I understand that we'll, as you know. And many of you would quite happily submit to US banks' KYC. But because you (and billions more around the world) either can't or won't, it is potentially  a game changer for US regulatory priorities.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jp_koning @GeorgeSelgin @CoinDesk Perhaps the upshot of both @GeorgeSelgin's point about surveillance-avoiding SC users being disinclined to initiate a bank run and @jp_koning's that regulators dropped the ball by not imposing KYC early on is that the latter must now choose the lesser of two evils to tolerate.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jp_koning @GeorgeSelgin @CoinDesk Possibly, but it's notable that the issue that is drawing most commentary from regulators is financial stability not KYC - as if they do see it having a potentially bigger impact in the future.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Gonzo_MM @GeorgeSelgin @Kiffmeister @jp_koning @CoinDesk Yes. But it amounts to the same: you never have to redeem the USD stablecoins into "real" dollars (in fact, can't), and if more and more people around the world think the same, the issue of reserve integrity becomes an afterthought.

@brendanlane00 @ZLOK @GeorgeSelgin That's a factor, yes, but it's inseparable from the problem of coercion and the problem of power dynamics. 

Imagine a scenario where a bitcoin-rich wholesaler uses the weight of the law to force a digitally ill-prepared farmer to accept an even lower USD price for his grain.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @baijorge Here, start with this: https://t.co/wWp9MOZkCH

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @BiasKnox @CoinDesk @GeorgeSelgin I hope you're right. Maybe it plays out such that the short-term inconvenience is outweighed by widespread digital/financial inclusion and energy independence. But setting it up as is, without explicit efforts to assure the latter, make it a risky bet in my mind.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @baijorge Really? My God, man, read my stuff before you conclude that I'm a fan of US laws!!!!

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @ZLOK @GeorgeSelgin I can see a path where this ends up as a bitcoin version of the "curse of OPEC," with El Salvador becoming a digiital version of "resource-rich" extraction economy in which the dividends from "mining" are exploited by a privileged elite, but do little to  help the majority.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @ZLOK @GeorgeSelgin Not accusing you of being high-fiver. And appreciate your serious analysis, as well as the fact that, yes, a bold political move is needed. But I worry that this could all go pear shaped.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @brendanlane00 @ZLOK @GeorgeSelgin In El Salvador, "merchants" are mostly the poorest: food vendors, small-plot farmers, etc. Do they have the tech chops to bridge the digital divide? Will the complicated exchange infrastructure be in place in time to guarantee such ppl aren't left holding unwanted, volatile BTC?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Not that I support USD sanctions. But these models have the capacity to be exploited by undemocratic, authoritarians. I want to be pleasantly surprised that Bukele is not one of them, but need to see more.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @ZLOK @GeorgeSelgin ...Otherwise this could simply be a mechanism for enriching a government that has few checks and balances on its power. A friendlier version of Iran allowing tax payments from govt.-sanctioned BTC miners to get around USD sanctions...

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @ZLOK @GeorgeSelgin It's a strawman to suggest my critique = pro-US approach. As I said, I support proactive govt measures and believe developing nations have the best opportunity to lead. But it needs more explicit focus on enabling access and utility for excluded people...

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @ZLOK @GeorgeSelgin But there's no talk of any such proactive ideas. Just a hardcore legal tender law, "volcano money," and lots of dudes high-fiving and platitudes about sovereign money.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @ZLOK @GeorgeSelgin Now, if El Salvador were to do support the expansion of mining-funded local solar microgrids, that would be an awesome use of this strategy - pro financial inclusion and pro-renewables growth. https://t.co/5syNizAFW0

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @ZLOK @GeorgeSelgin More worrying, it hints at the authoritarian instincts that Bukele's political critics cite. And that has me worried about the motives behind legalizing bitcoin, especially with the capacity for his government to do a giant money grab with its state-run "volcano mine."

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @ZLOK @GeorgeSelgin I think there are all sorts of proactive things a government can do to encourage bitcoin adoption as a financial inclusion tool, including a normal, modest comparatively lightweight legal tender rule - as per George's definition. But Article 7 goes too far.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
There are all sorts of problems with El Salvador and Bukele being the poster child for bitcoin as a route to financial freedom. 

@GeorgeSelgin does a good job of laying out one of the main ones.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@HernanFerrando1 @CoinDesk Which sadly means the bitcoin will be controlled by large, centralized entities, or in the case of state-run nuclear, by the government. 

I want community ownership (of power and bitcoin). Solar is the energy source most widely spread across diverse populations. Let's go there.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@HernanFerrando1 @CoinDesk Hydro, hydrogen and nuclear are good, clean sources - much better than fossil fuel - but because they operate at scale they revert to centralized models of control. 

I'm interested in decentralizing the grid (for both security and social impact reasons), not just green sources.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@HernanFerrando1 @CoinDesk Yes, those wind-bent trees in Patagonia speak to it. But you get the biggest social inclusion+environmental impact in developing multiple, smaller, integrated energy sources that are close to many separate communities. 

This is why I like the network of solar microgrids model.

tweet: @dandolfa @sheila_warren Separately, will say more in a column this week, but I think there are other forms of "sovereignty" -  e.g. independent energy policy - that bitcoin could enable which will outweigh any cost from lost fiat monetary sovereignty.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @dandolfa @sheila_warren Whether it's dollarization or bitcoin, fiat monetary sovereignty is impossible for places with deepseated historical structural issues. They have no choice but "not to trust ourselves." The choice is dollar (colonialism) or something else external.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@dandolfa Clever David, but unfair. There's copious literature on the legacy reasons why many poor countries' finances are in bad shape

see @sheila_warren 's & my podcast on Haiti slavery debt, e.g.

Should such places be forever condemned to monetary colonialism?

https://t.co/P8j9Kvd2DB

tweet: @f_j_j_ Exchanges will set up in friendly jurisdictions and soonnn get their fiat from CBDCs and/or stablecoins. US gatekeeping power is on last legs. POW miners can go anywhere. Exchanges too. Authoritarian state hash power proves the point. Better to entice that into green US projects.

tweet: @f_j_j_ OK. And how, exactly?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@f_j_j_ Also, curious what you'd do if these miners, deterred from their Montana deal, seek a coal-fired solution instead. 

Like climate change, bitcoin isn't going away - whether you like ot or not. It can't be banned globally. So what then? Surely the answer is: encourage green mining

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @f_j_j_ But your point about solar materials costs suggests you think the only solution you want is to to stop economic activity, which translates into condemning the underprivileged everywhere to stagnation. We need growth. We need renewable energy. We must fund both.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @f_j_j_ It isn't. But it's by far the fastest. Absence of readily deployable risk capital is the biggest drag on renewable development. Here comes an investor to accelerate deployment because of an immediate ROI and you turn it away? Why do you think the deal was done in the first place?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@jfuriously Jack's great, but that's a flawed narrative. Subsidies for green energy merely counter the hidden subsidies fossil fuel producers enjoyed for a century.

It's about externalities. Paid for by us. About Big Oil feeloading on the the costs WE pay for pollution and climate change.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@SnakeEyes_MM To remove that subsidy, govts should tax (or even ban) access to fossil fuel plants like this - for miners or anyone.

Miners will go where energy is cheap. The legacy of not taxing fossil fuel producers for the costs society bears on their behalf means miners will still go there

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@SnakeEyes_MM A WSJ article this week talked of all the once dormant coal plants being restarted to service Bitcoin miners. Not good.

The economics of that flow from a de facto subsidy. The installed capacity of those plants was paid for by society in the form of environmental externalities.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @BrettKing @CoinDesk @chainyoda If not, then, yes, self-interested, amoral bitcoin miners will keep using fossil fuel sources in places where the policy framework makes those otherwise expensive options artificially cheap. And in that case, yes, Bitcoin's carbon footprint becomes a problem.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @BrettKing @CoinDesk @chainyoda We need enlightened policy makers - energy policy makers (at national and city levels) - to recognize the intersection of these interests (and the inevitability of both bitcoin and a green future) to speed up this process.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @BrettKing @CoinDesk @chainyoda By offering revenue guarantees to green energy projects and striking deals with operators of  solar-dominant grid, Bitcoin miners can play a hugely catalytic role in underwriting the development of energy systems built on renewable models.

name: Michael J. Casey
Michael J. Casey
tweet: @BrettKing @CoinDesk Agree. Unlike @chainyoda (saw your battery tweet earlier Ajit), I believe Bitcoin can be an accelerator of this process. But it won't happen magically on its own. We need a policy framework that encourages Bitcoin miners to support green energy projects  and eschew fossil fuels

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @MazMHussain @matthew_petti @AntonJaegermm @paulvigna @harari_yuval Absolutely. Human organization, our greatest achievement, depends on our ability to tell and share stories that resonate and convey meaning. The idea of a nation state is a constructed story. It is not founded in anything natural. Yet it is the foundation of the world order.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @MazMHussain @matthew_petti @AntonJaegermm @paulvigna @harari_yuval @AntonJaegermm is onto something re metallism antecedents. Per Felix Martin's "Money: The Unauthorized Biography," money is not the physical "thing;" it's a "social technology." But we need the myth of "the thing" - gold's magical appeal - to make the social "story" of money work

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @MazMHussain @matthew_petti @AntonJaegermm @paulvigna @harari_yuval That Bitcoin has all that in spades is a strength, not a weakness. After all, the most successful money in history is laden with quasi-religious and other cultural meaning. See: the insane imagery on a dollar note. Why does US currency have the words" "In God we Trust" on it?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @MazMHussain @matthew_petti @AntonJaegermm @paulvigna Also, money itself. As @harari_yuval says, money is the greatest story ever told. It requires *belief*. So any project to create a new money inevitably wends its way into a process of cultural production: myths, icons, memes, etc.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@chainyoda @yorkerhodes @nitingaur @baselineproto @pbrody @IBMBlockchain @jwolpert So we can all be friends again? 

Though I won't be able to sleep until @pbrody tells me it's all OK. :)

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @chainyoda @yorkerhodes @nitingaur @baselineproto @pbrody @IBMBlockchain Good point on funding. But it's separate from the core value prop, which to me is that a truly decentralized data-sharing system (which permissionless crypto is currently closest to) will allow a new business model in which companies figure out how to profit while sharing data.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @yorkerhodes It's those who don't understand the role of a native crypto token in a permissionless blockchain. It's not that I see no value in private blockchains. I'm just taking a dig at all the companies who asked me to speak, saying "please don't talk about bitcoin, just blockchain."

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @chainyoda @yorkerhodes @nitingaur @baselineproto @pbrody @IBMBlockchain I confess to being ill-informed about Baseline Protocol. You've all inspired me to look into it. Sounds encouraging. My job here was to just try to get the Fortune 500 conversation focused on the right thing...

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @yorkerhodes @nitingaur @baselineproto @pbrody @IBMBlockchain @chainyoda @paulcurrion Recognize that problem, work together to address it, use blockchain/DLT/SQL database, whatever, and then we have the start of a solution. But don't sell magic solutions. It will only set us back. Meanwhile, the massive failures of our current capitalism will multiply. That is all

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @yorkerhodes @nitingaur @baselineproto @pbrody @IBMBlockchain @chainyoda @paulcurrion Blockchains, DLT, crypto, call it what you will, have the "potential" - and only if we do what's necessary to empower it  - to address one small but crucial element of this failure: a capacity to collectively verify certain claims without relying on an all-powerful institution...

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@yorkerhodes @nitingaur @baselineproto @pbrody @IBMBlockchain @chainyoda Related... hear me out: I was impacted today by this @paulcurrion essay. It not only helped me with the language we struggle with - "trust" v "confidence" - it reminded me why bitcoin inspired me in the 1st place: recognition that institutions fail us...

 https://t.co/y08Z6R2yCa

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @yorkerhodes @nitingaur @baselineproto @pbrody @IBMBlockchain And to my pal @chainyoda, happy for you to have at me. But when you do, let's spar in this spirit: the entire "DLT/blockchain" space (whatever we call it), needs a level set. Is there a problem with incumbent, centralized data systems? Hell yeah. So, how can this community help?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @yorkerhodes @nitingaur @baselineproto @pbrody @IBMBlockchain And one last point - missed it seems by my critics among both the bitcoin maxis AND the "blockchain-without-bitcoin" fools - the takeaway is that enterprises need to embrace the disruptive dynamism of public blockchains or they'll die. How was that apologetic to IBM?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @yorkerhodes @nitingaur @baselineproto @pbrody @IBMBlockchain I'm trying to speak - admittedly imperfectly - to execs confused by the failure of what IBM (partly) led them to see as quick fixes. That's it! I'm sorry, but your demanding I list other projects sounds just like the crypto tribes who demand we cover this or that coin. Context.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @yorkerhodes @nitingaur @baselineproto Yorke, with respect, I think you & @pbrody misread my point - maybe our headline set expectations wrong. It's not a show-and-tell of non-IBM wins. It's that C-suites were misled by "BaaS" as an easy fix, and i think it clearly assigns a chunk of blame so that to @IBMBlockchain

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @NeerajKA Spoken like a true Global Leader

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @pbrody Paul, you were literally called out in the article!

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @steve_alarm @dgwbirch I now think not - at least not in the transitional phase where it needs to establish itself as sound money - but the goal needs to eventually be that it stabilizes.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mikekelly85 @jameswester @dgwbirch It might. And if that's truly consensus, presumably it's because the majority in that utopian network saw a less regressive monetary policy in its common interest. But I think permanent, confirmed scarcity is bitcoin's value prop. The bigger issue is what gets built on top of it

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@dgwbirch @jameswester Just a thesis, and it's years/decades off. But the open-source nature of the development underway holds some hope of something like that eventually happening. 

Excessive KYC will stall, but hopefully not kill, its progress.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @dgwbirch @jameswester Well, one thesis is that eventually, once it has passed through a speculative phase, stabilizes, and is widely accepted as digital gold, it can then becomes something more powerful: the base-layer, programmable collateral of a new, peer-to-peer, open-access financial system.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jameswester @dgwbirch Not sure how that squares with the bitcoin is a Eurodollar-like system for letting the rich evade control.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jameswester @dgwbirch But I still believe the biggest barrier to allowing more equitable participation in crypto is excessive regulation - KYC etc. - which will make it easier for compliance-obsessed institutions to get in at these levels but very hard for the marginalized poor.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jameswester @dgwbirch I don't think @dgwbirch, of all people, believes you can only buy a whole bitcoin. And 10x on $100 is still nothing to scoff at. I imagine the point is more that the capacity to HODL/take risky bets is generally easier if you're well off.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @dgwbirch Eurodollar market is a good analogy, though. Interesting article too.

name: Michael J. Casey

It's at the root of all this dysfunction.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @kofinas @HiddenForcesPod @triciawang Which is why censorship IS an issue, even though platforms are entitled to it  It's also why, notwithstanding that Trump's completely self-serving effort to repeal S.230 would do more harm than good, there's a real problem with the publisher/platform contradiction in their status

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@kofinas @HiddenForcesPod In our podcast -- which we'll get you on soon, Demetri - @triciawang made the astute observation that life on Facebook is like living in a company town -- a life of dependency on that institution makes it very hard to leave. 

 https://t.co/iBYp8LGFUT

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @kofinas @HiddenForcesPod We'd have to figure out what constitutes a big enough size for a platform to be deemed a monopoly. But by the "duck test," it's hard to argue Twitter and FB AREN'T monopolies - Trumpies wouldn't be upset they weren't.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @kofinas @HiddenForcesPod Their curation algorithms need to be regulated. Their capacity to create and manipulate our data feeds with secret algorithms is a far bigger problem than censorship IMHO, but doesn't get as much attentions.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @kofinas @HiddenForcesPod Yep. Regulation on monopoly grounds offer a way out of this dilemma. They retain their right as private entities to censor (necessary in some cases to protect the public interest) but given their data monopolization, that power comes at a cost.

tweet: 3/4 It's a fertile environment for conspiracy theories and uncompromising stances. It's why Qanon thrives among the right, why liberals can't empathize with any Trump voter, and why to crypto folks it can seem like the only thing going on is a bitcoin maxi vs eth fanboy war.  3/4

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: 2/4 Twitter, Google and FB's interests lie in delivering us - neatly packaged into what Facebook calls "like" audiences - to advertisers. So they curate our news feeds and funnel us into similarly minded echo chambers in which our confirmation biases are affirmed constantly

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: 1/4 Yes! Too few people recognize this. Metcalfe's Law has given these centralized platforms' unprecedented control over humanity's mindshare, a power they execute not out of some nefarious interest in censoring or manipulating society per se but because THAT's the business model

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
12/12 That said, I am supremely confident we'll achieve this. By adding TradeBlock’s data to our mix, we're in the best position to write the biggest story in finance, a centuries-in-the-making story of the disruption of money. My blog post on the above: 
https://t.co/DYmUGf1PAX

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
11/12 Here’s the thing: For this combo to work, CoinDesk must continue to earn the trust of its audience regardless of their business/market interest. It's why my biggest 
obligation as Chief Content Officer is to safeguard our journalism's independence. https://t.co/qnP71uazIY

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: 10/12 This powerful combination mixes CoinDesk’s news, events and research products – whose global audiences comprise millions of early adopters, retail investors, startups and other interested parties – with a suite of TradeBlock tools to attract the institutions.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: 9/12 Enter CoinDesk+TradeBlock. Start with the oldest, most trusted pedigree in crypto journalism, with unparalleled insights into the crypto ecosystem; add a new team offering the industry's most advanced price, indexes and data. (@CoinDesk_CEO's take: https://t.co/4dcR9BdivS)

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: 8/12 It’s no secret that in crypto markets, prices, volumes, market cap calculations and other exchange-generated information are inconsistent. That’s a problem for the big institutions now piling in as bitcoin surges to all-time highs. They will demand robust, reliable data.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: 7/12 Now is the time – after the FTSE, Nikkei and DJIA told the story of 20th-century capitalism – to introduce new reference price and indexing tools that can tell the tale of the 21st century’s emerging decentralized financial system and crypto economy.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: 6/12 If there’s no trust, whether among licensees, other media, or the general public, reference prices and indexes fail as benchmarks. But if they’re transparent, based on sophisticated models from secure data sources and protected by a trusted media brand, users will adopt them

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: 5/12 So, it’s natural this story-telling role falls to trusted media brands - those making a constant effort to get the story right, regardless of whether the truth harms any vested interest. Such outlets are ideally placed to foster trust in the integrity of the numbers.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: 4/12 When accepted as shared sources of truth, prices and indexes are powerful narrative devices. The story they tell enables decision-making and societal consensus around our confidence in the state of the world. But to play that role, prices and indexes must be trusted.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: 3/12 More than that, those media-managed indexes became proxies for their economies. They function as bellwethers of our periodic booms and busts. They tell the story of the ongoing struggle between demand and supply and offer snapshots of our economic well being.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: 2/12 Think of the @FinancialTimes’ FTSE 100, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun’s @Nikkei 225 and Dow Jones & Co’s Dow Jones Industrial Average. Each is owned by a trusted news outlet. Each has for decades been the benchmark market indicator in the U.K., Japan and U.S., respectively.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
5/5 That's mostly 'cos the "hunt for Satoshi" proved futile. 

Still, it's a notable new phase in the popular narrative.

Satoshi-as-unidentifiable-founder is no longer a problem to solve. It's unquestioned lore.

A sign we're nearing a Kubla Ross "acceptance" phase for Bitcoin?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
4/5 What's striking now is how that story has drifted into the background. 

I'm sure we'll get many "Satoshi is xth-richest person in the world" stories soon.  (Currently about 20th?) 

But there really isn't the same obsession with figuring out who the founder is.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: 3/5 I also recall intense interest from law enforcement/regulatory agencies in all the theories. Get Satoshi, it was thought, and they'd have someone to subpoena.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
2/5 Mainstream journalists were obsessed for the next few years. Everyone had a theory: @NickSzabo4? NSA? John Nash? @adam3us? Shinichi Mochizuki( per Ted Nelson.) 

Who can forget @Newsweek "finding" him hiding in plain site: Dorian Nakamoto. 👆

And then we got the CSW circus!

@tushar_io @jp_koning @CoinDesk I think you are missing the nuance. 

This column, to which I think @jp_koning is obliquely referring, lays out my position. 

Bitcoin is a powerful catalyst for positive societal change - precisely because it is a bet against the current broken order. 

https://t.co/FXTt6QrOA6

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @_drgo @RaoulGMI Maybe, yes. The whole thing is pretty damn dicey.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @RaoulGMI Looking forward to digging into all this in our respective podcasts.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @RaoulGMI A debt jubilee will, after all, make a mockery of the notion that US Treasurys bonds, or any other sovereign debt instruments, deserve their status as "risk-free" benchmarks. Much better that we use bitcoin as a universal base-level reserve asset instead.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @RaoulGMI In other words, a system that doesn't use the debt of nation states as its collateral base. A system built on smart contracts and scarce, decentralized, depoliticized digital stores of value to replace our inherently flawed dependence on government-issued "risk-free" assets.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @RaoulGMI I think the answer will come with new technologies - bitcoin is part of that, as is DeFi, AI and SSI - that enables that vital element of financialization and speculation to thrive independently of the legacy macro infrastructure...

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @RaoulGMI It can't just be that equities is the only asset class left. That ignores the integral role that credit markets play in driving speculation and value creation. The question of what comes after this must take those innate needs into account.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @RaoulGMI I see a similar trajectory - and let's face it, a coordinated debt jubilee is a better outcome than all-out war. But the question is, where does this leave capitalism? Or, better put, where does it leave entrepreneueship and it's need for finance?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @pierre_rochard @Nouriel Got it. Agree that @michael_saylor has done a great job highlighting the long-term why bitcoin case. But it underscores a bigger point: make the message appealing and clear and make it consistent. Otherwise the "it's too volatile" story is too easy to tell.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @pierre_rochard @Nouriel Not condoning - obviously - but it means those of us who believe in bitcoin should drive home a message that a short-termist economy has made difficult for people to grasp: pthe payoff lies in the future.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @pierre_rochard @Nouriel Sure. But in a world designed to constantly reward dopamine releases, "stupid" wins every time.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @_drgo @pierre_rochard @Nouriel I think the defining problem of our age lies in the fact that short-termist perspectives offer immediate profit while the ROI from something that offers long-term societal benefit is hard to monetize.

name: Michael J. Casey
Michael J. Casey
tweet: @_drgo @pierre_rochard @Nouriel Yep. It's a case study of a host other problems: e.g. the primacy of quarterly results to the stock market's rhythms, or the short time horizons of electoral cycles. The nice thing about the bitcoin thesis is it fundamentally ignores such short-termism. Because it's irrelevant.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
If you believe in something, Goddamit, stand up for it!

Put your personal reputation on the line. (This can even be the reputation of a pseudonym; read @MarcHochstein for nuance on this.)

Hiding behind a stolen or deliberately deceptive identity is a snowflake's tactic...17/17

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
Now, more than ever, we must be honest with each other. If you want to push an ideology, or argue with others, that's fine.

And sometimes, for security, you need a pseudonym. 

But that MUST be distinguished from deliberate, deceptive, manipulative subterfuge...16/17

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: I support startups striving for these new truth models in social media, whether for content itself or for traffic data independent of Google/FB/Twitter et al. (I even founded one myself: @thestreambed) But until utopia is found, let's spare a thought for journalism...15/17

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: There are a host of potential solutions to this dilemma.  Some involve blockchain, others not. But they all seek to assign a cost, in a decentralized, uncontrollable setting such as Twitter, to the act of disseminating information in a way that discourages lies... 14/17

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Squaring those competing objectives (truth vs privacy) requires attaching cost to information. Journalists typically aspire to name their sources: if you're on the record, you're less likely to lie, given reputational cost. But in the social media age, it's complicated... 13/17

name: Michael J. Casey
Michael J. Casey
tweet:
So, that was fun. But here's why it's actually quite serious: 

If it's not obvious, as we come out of the most divisive election in history, disinformation over social media has profound consequences. (See the work of @graphika_NYC, MIT's Sinan Arai, Geoff Golberg)... 11/17

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
Oh, also.. to the account's one other follower:

Hey, @swaaanson of @thumbtack, why follow @kara_lindsey? Did you mistake this for the real @KaraLindsay1? 

Or were you so moved by her/his/its poetic tweets? ("Nope, dumbass;" "Lol Fox News is now controlled by leftists")... 10/17

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
So, I'll assume, @KaraLindsay1, that @kara_lindsey has stolen your likeness. (I suggest asking @jack and co. to shut it down. Maybe this one too: @KaraLindsxy1) 

Maybe one day, when NYC lets us do so again, we can share a drink to discuss this weird intersection of lives... 9/17

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Well, a search of the profile image showed it does belong to a real person: Kara Lindsay (spelled with an a, not an e),  an NYC-based actress (Newsies, Wicked). Kara's a #BLM supporter, a mask-wearer, a proud new mother, an all round good person, from what I can tell... 8/17

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
But there's more... 

Typically a bot's handle is mostly numbers. In this case it was very clean. "Kara-underscore-Lindsey." A totally new account, with a rather common name, still available in almost pristine state. Was it actually a real person? ... 7/17

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
So, question: Is Nick Szabo, the would-be Bitcoin mastermind-turned-MAGA man, somehow behind this idiotic troll account?

The coincidence, given the subject matter and our past differences over it, seems too big.

Why? (I find it bafflingly sad, given his brilliant mind)... 6/17

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: NOTE: Nick, despite his libertarian leanings (which, call me stupid, I think should equate with open borders), is vehemently anti-immigrant. So, at some point during an exchange on Twitter in which I took issue with Trump's fascist attacks on refugees, he blocked me... 5/17

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Digging deeper, things got weird. One of the ONLY TWO followers is @NickSzabo4, whom I, like many crypto journalists, have followed over the years for his major contribution to #bitcoin indirectly (or directly, if you accept @nathanielpopper's Satoshi thesis) ... 4/17 https://t.co/leOy6xEpBY

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
I got a quick trolly reply, an unsophisticated, child-like response: "Nope, dumbass." 

It piqued my interest. Who/what is @kara_lindsey?

Sure enough, I encountered bot-like features: Account started November 2020, three reply/tweets since Nov 13, and just two followers... 3/17

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
It starts with my retweet of @profgalloway's take on a big drop in international student registrations at US colleges.

To me, my question was reasonable, given how many Nobel Prizes are won by former immigrant students who are now US academics... 2/17 https://t.co/11vyKuJI1v

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
I usually follow @revilopark's advice to "never feed the trolls," but this was too weird, comical. I couldn't resist. 

What follows is a strange tale involving @NickSzabo4 and the (presumably unaware) Broadway actress @KaraLindsay1. 

A thread I wrote up last night... 1/17

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @AnicyberUS No global governance system lasts forever. The current, U.S.-led one has lasted since the end of World War 2. It's hard to predict when it will fall apart, but when it does you want to own something that's uncorrelated with that meltdown. I think that's a compelling concept.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@NoelleInMadrid @chamath @laurashin Hmm. Good question. I'd say it's the post-WWII, Bretton Woods era ruling class. So "current" means the past 76 years. 

The post-meltdown ruling class will sit atop a very different system.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: That's why putting 1% of a portfolio in bitcoin and forgetting about it - "don't look at it" - is a compelling idea. You hope the system survives and thrives, so the other 99% grows and the 1% goes to zero. But if it all falls apart, your 1% goes to 120% and "you like a genius."

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Short-term analysis would suggest @chamath's point on bitcoin's un-correlation is wrong. BTC & equities have been tightly aligned lately. Gold's proving a better safe haven. But he really means it's a long-term insurance policy against everything going to hell in a hand basket.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @chamath @laurashin Also: Bitcoin is "a bet against the ruling class."

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jgharris7 I really hope I haven't wasted my time spurting all this out to you, because your knee jerk critiques of my work don't usually allow for such nuance. But in your false equivalence between digital bank money and digital currency I saw an opportunity to set the record straight.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jgharris7 I think PBOC will achieve de facto programmability because, while it will monitor transaction and identify wallet holders (the v. scary part), it badly wants to enable smart city and other initiatives. I also think  a compliant Chinese population will treat it as digital cash.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jgharris7 So the proof, somewhat, is in how it functions in real life, in the degree of trust people have that their transactions are non-reversible. (Pethaos we'll learn that only true censorship resistant money like bitcoin can be truly programmable).

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jgharris7 I don't think a CB is an intermediary as a commercial bank is because it's the sovereign issuer and intends the CBDC to be an instantly settled bearer instrument. If it reversed transactions it would lose that cash-like function and, yes, would be a de facto intermediary.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jgharris7 You mightn't care but a digital device like a pallet mover in a supply chain or a smart meter in a decentralized electricty grid will. Instant, programmable settlement - which Zelle cannot do - enables automation in commerce and community resource management like we've never seen

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @ClemondNFlinch Probably, yes, but only at the account level. I think the whole point is to enable automatic, peer-to-peer settlement between pre-authorized accounts. So two parties can write DCEP-consistent logic into their transactions for direct, programmable machine-to-machine clearing.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @ClemondNFlinch If we think solely about the issuance/monetary policy parameter (centralized vs decentralized protocol), yes. But the link between bitcoin and CBDC is, sadly, closer than we think. Like bitcoin, a CBCD is a digital bearer instrument - a bank-dependent mobile payment is not.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@jgharris7 Oh, how about actually settle directly, peer-to-per with your counterparty? 

That intermediary-free transactabilty is what makes digital currency so much more powerful than a digital bank account. It gives money itself - not just the online interface - the  power of software.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @isaac It's an economy of 1.3 b people. The internal advantages will be transformative. But, in any case, for the digital RMB to have cross-border power it just needs interoperability with another national digital currency. Cosmos is part of China's BSN. Watch for the digital ruble

tweet: @HappyMiddleNC @francispouliot_ @JustinWolfers Yes! That constitutional mandate renders impossible (or at least irrelevant) the prospect of a free market equilibrium for agencies like USPS. name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mdudas @TheStalwart Yep. That our highways don't have to make a profit (gas tax = a joke) while USPS does speaks volumes on our political system and priorities of those who control it.  Elsewhere in the world both highways AND postal services are "infrastructure." None of this BS debate even happens

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @francispouliot_ @HappyMiddleNC @JustinWolfers Not an economist here. (Just someone who plays one on TV.) Surely the problem lies with the fact that government "agencies" like USPS, whatever their mandate, can never be truly for-profit entities because the needs of the wider electorate compete with those of the profit motive

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jimcollins If we can figure out how to improve that trust part -- crypto can play a role -- we can do all sorts of cool MMT-inspired things, free ourselves from the fiscal straitjacket. But without that trust framework, yes, governments will revert to abusing their power.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jimcollins You're pigeonholing me. Please read me more closely. I am not a hard money hyperinflation alarmist. I'd call myself a crypto liberal. But I also know there is no free lunch. I think lefties don't understand the core relationship between trust, government and money....

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jimcollins @StephanieKelton @NathanTankus Many traditional economists are yelling at MMTers. They don't need my voice too. I do want to interview @stephaniekelton. My angle differs from ttradtionalists: I  think MMT framework is correct; but without an alternative trust mechanism governments will abuse it.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jimcollins That's not fair. You called crickets way too early.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jimcollins All we can say is, if you hold everything else constant, adding more currency into an economy of fixed X size will create inflation. In that scenario you could prolly measure the currency impact. But it's pointless because the real world doesn't conveniently stop still like that.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jimcollins Well, it kind of is rocket science, because the economy is an incredibly dynamic ecosystem of multiple moving parts. Nothing is constant. It's extremely difficult to measure these things.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jimcollins BTW, inflation-indexed bonds, in theory, protect bondholders against this kind of thing. But you need to trust the "oracle:" the government statistics agency that measures inflation.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jimcollins But in the context of that passage my point is that even without direct debt monetization like tha, Jim as sovereign has an interest in creating inflation, because it increases nominal incomes, which increases nominal tax receipts, making it easier to meet fixed debt repayments

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jimcollins First, those new Jim dollars sloshing around the economy are inherently inflationary. Monetizing  the debt rather than drawing tax revenue from real growth , means, all things being equal, the price of goods and services will rise because more Jim dollars are now chasing them.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @MishaGuttentag @CoinDesk Great question! I don't think we're yet in a global currency competition. But that day is rapidly coming - driven by waning faith in the dollar hegemon and by tech (cryptocurrencies/CBDCs). When, we get there, I agree, it might impose a kind of Hayekian market discipline on govts

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @joonian Hah. Had forgotten you'd become an MMTer!  I'd say the deficit myth harms policymaking but not sure it's shirking responsibility, as politicians' responsibility is (rightly or wrongly) to manage those deficits. I worry that w/t political risk of taxation, accountability is lost.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
What to like about MMT and what to run away from...

And how might crypto help?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: In that sense, per @LulaEDUcate, it's perhaps important to distinguish Apple, which makes most of its money from device sales and so is incentivized to promise its users privacy, from Google/Facebook, which make money from hawking your data to advertisers. 5/5

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: The question may be whether that monopolistic control is a price we're willing to pay for important features such as privacy. 4/5

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: These gatekeepers DO quash innovation, esp. in payments. Dynamic new business models loom for creators with NFTs/crypto payments, including collaborations with users. Gaming leads this but it applies to all media creators. Apple is, effectively, blocking that innovation. 3/5

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
But I still think we need to "de-platform the platforms."

Core problem: our dependency on GAFA's oligopoly. (Apple's included because IOS device dominance enables gatekeeping power akin to Google's search dominance, Amazon's marketplace dominance, and FB's social dominance). 2/5

name: Michael J. Casey

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@_drgo @NYTimesCohen 1. An 11th-hour federal lawsuit stopping Seattle from barring tear gas. 
2. Trump's perpetual use of "law and order" and racist tropes, incitements of violence at rallies.
3. Pledging the Portland model to Chicago, NYC etc. 
4. Just about every anti-immigration order he's made

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @_drgo @NYTimesCohen I think CV case is different. The virus ignores borders; it's inherently national (international really). Needs a coordinated response. But, yeah, I was worried the crisis spawned by the pandemic would be used as an excuse for a power grab. Didn't expect it to play out this way.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @_drgo @NYTimesCohen The power imbalance in the scenario you describe is why it is by far the lesser of two evils. As you well know, only the federal government has the power to print legal tender and to maintain a military. Bottom-up tyranny is a pipsqueak against top-down tyranny.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @_drgo @NYTimesCohen Over time living in this country I've come to respect the dispersal of power across states and cities as a valuable, decentralizing bulwark against the absolute power of the center. I see nothing but a deliberate move to erode that here. It scares the shit out of me.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @_drgo @NYTimesCohen You keep wanting to reduce this to a simple black & white / good v bad narrative. The reason the @NYTimesCohen piece matters is because history contains lessons about how these narratives can be used to install dehumanizing power structures.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @_drgo @NYTimesCohen It upsets me, in fact baffles the hell out of me, that libertarians like you support this.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @_drgo @NYTimesCohen The unmarked cars story is irrelevant. This is a federal power grab in the name of "law and order." Using "criminals" language enables that. It's the bigger game here that matters: Demonizing liberal communities to garner populist support for the suppression of opposition voices

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @_drgo @NYTimesCohen That sounds like distraction. name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jeetsidhu_ @francispouliot_ The issue isn't (the ambiguously defined) measure of money supply a fractional reserve system, but whether the Fed retains institutional (i.e. apoliticized) control over it. name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jeetsidhu_ @francispouliot_ Yes, the Fed balance sheet expansion has been dangerously steep, but you posted a really misleading chart. name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @harmonylion1 @balajis @William_Blake @RichardDawkins @thegoddisk Happy to see those boundaries pushed.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @BensonNalle @balajis @William_Blake @RichardDawkins I fear you're right. It doesn't diminish the relevance of memetics to understanding how ideas spread, but we should think hard about how to architect social media systems, not with top-down control (i.e. censorship) but with a dynamic capacity for smart nuanced ideas to compete.

name: Michael J. Casey
Michael J. Casey
tweet: @harmonylion1 @balajis @William_Blake @RichardDawkins @thegoddisk Cool. I struggle with that leap from TikTok videos to Juice Wrld's actual death but maybe because our understanding of such phenomena is so nascent... 1/2

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @balajis @William_Blake @RichardDawkins And, yes, it's perfect for Internet memes. (I only say the word has been hijacked because people don't take it seriously.) Internet memes are a subset of a much wider concept, but a very clear illustration of it. Social media has accelerated memetic reproduction.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @balajis @William_Blake @RichardDawkins 💯 Our science, language and descriptive capacity are unable to isolate and define each meme as an observable phenomenon in, say, a lab. But we can observe their effects and hypothesize on how they function. Memetics is a greatly under-appreciated field.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @MatiasVolco @balajis @William_Blake @RichardDawkins I'd say so, yes, but it's also his ideologies, scientific theories and political movements spread and become entrenched. Memes are the building blocks of human knowledge and culture.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @William_Blake @balajis @RichardDawkins All this, btw, was covered in @revilopark's and my book about social media and biomimcry, The Social Organism. https://t.co/oph85gMDcc

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @William_Blake @balajis @RichardDawkins It's not about the neuron. The meme is the cultural unit itself - an idea, a song, a celebrity, an, image, a hashtag. Anything that lodges in our collective mindshare and spreads. Most importantly, it's a building block for other ideas - it evolves, just as social media memes do.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @William_Blake @balajis @RichardDawkins The name got hijacked. The Selfish Gene was published in 1976, long before cat videos were a thing.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @balajis Wasn't that @RichardDawkins point when he coined the word "meme" in The Selfish Gene? A unit of cultural expression that competes with other memes to occupy our limited mindshare plant and so replicate itself, much like a gene.

P2P #bitcoin surging in Africa.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola Sure.  But rapidly reducing the dollar's status to a fraction of where it is now would have massive domino effects. A reason to avoid it, yes, but then we get back to the drug analogy... We'll go round and round on this. I really gotta go...

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola And before it happens, as people start to worry about that, a properly reserved stablecoin (T-bills, not FDIC banks) provides some protection against bank failures (esp. for foreign companies that need dollars and are dependent on foreign USD accounts).

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola Look, to be clear, I'm not making a case for stablecoins. If USD collapses, of course SCs would go too. I'm trying to suggest that the core structures upon which faith exists in banks generally -- and political will to support them - isn't as indefinitely sustainable as ppl think

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola One last point, since you asked: Why must there be a single reserve currency? It might be desirable, but interoperable exchange rate escrow between CBDCs might make it unnecessary to use a common trading currency. We assume the world must look one way. It doesn't have to.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola I very much hope you are right. But we live in starkly different times. Our governments' resources aren't boundless. They're dependent on political support - or violence. The countries you and I live in are both having a hard time garnering the former right now. Anyway, gotta run

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola I disagree. Argentina taught me to understand the core problem of money, trust and government - which is why it IS transferable. The parallels with the US right now are striking. And I wasn't scarred!!! I loved it there. As an expat, I was a lucky one...

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola Also obviously, it's a much harder peg to break. Because the dependency is so, so big, with so much riding on it...

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola That's the ultimate test. OBVIOUSLY, it seems an unlikely problem now, because the whole world needs dollars. But that's the actual problem. Dependency. (As with Argentina's peg to the dollar).

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola Sorry, I mean USD as world's reserve currency. not a point about stablecoins.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola Sorry. I mean the US dollar as the world's reserve currency. So, yes, category error. But one attached to a completely different point.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola It all depends on whether we believe that Argentin-ization of developed world banking systems would ever be possible. As I said, I used to think not. I'm no longer so confident.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola Of course. But I see a longer term House of Cards problem - with the ultimate test, as with Argentina, being the public's political will - in trying to orchestrate ongoing bank bailouts in a crisis as big as the Great Depression. I hope not. But we have to talk about it

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@Frances_Coppola Problem is crypto companies already have only a very small number of banks willing to take a risk on them. (
And it IS strategic and/or bad perception/image that's stopping other banks in many cases, not real risk per se.) Those startups really need to keep their bankers close

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola I would have agreed two years ago. I think Argentina is exactly the lesson that the developed world needs to take. The issue of USD reserves role (creating imbalances that will eventually bite the US) can even be compared (somewhat) to the peso peg. It's great until it's not.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola The regulatory framework and auditing rigor that Paxos and CENTRE are subjected to is like night and day to Bitfinex/Tether. I don't think it's a reasonable benchmark. Sure, who knows what unforeseen counterparty risks lurk in their models? (But banks? Remember 2008...)

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
@JuanLlanos Right. But it seems to me that should be put more in T-bills and less in cash -- which, of course, isn't really "cash."
It's exposure to a fractional reserve banking system.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola Not many, I'm sure. I'm on the fence as to which. In the context of COVID-19 and what it portends, I tend to think a well-audited stablecoin held in T-bills will end up safer than quite a few banks. But I was in Argentina post-2001, so my thinking might be skewed on risks.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola Right, but it's extremely rare -- and scary, as we know from the Reserve Fund debacle of 2008 -- for it to break the buck. T-bills is a safer, more liquid place to be in a full-on banking crisis, unless the USG goes into default,  in which case all bets are off anyway...

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola I'd be interested to hear your thoughts on the questions I pose in the thread following that tweet.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: The power of incumbency is extremely strong in the financial system.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: If, alternatively, it's that banks won't provide account services if issuers don't hold more reserves with them, there's some classic  irony here. Akin to frustration felt by so many bitcoin startups: to create a system that bypasses banks, first you need a bank account.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Is it because banks will cut them off from a having the functional bank accounts they (currently) need if they don't hold X amount of their reserves with them?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: What's stopping stablecoin issuers from going Full Monte and holding reserves in money market accounts? Is it because customers (mistakenly, I'd say) feel safer with funds placed in an insured, regulated bank rather than a heavily audited asset management account? Or..

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: A lot of these projects talk up the idea that an asset manager invests the reserves in Treasurys. USDC and PAX have portions in T-bill etc, but it seems most reserves are in bank accounts. And as @Frances_Coppola points out, FDIC insurance only goes so far.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
See @Frances_Coppola's response to my Money Reimagined piece on COVID-19 USD stablecoin demand. Solid point that if reserves are held in bank accounts, not invested in standalone liquid assets, users aren't really less at risk of fractional reserve risks
https://t.co/8iUFUvqdGt

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
Accelerating toward the halving? 

Answer: Not necessarily. The randomness that delivered this outcome could just as well throw a number of 8-block hours our way between now and the halving block. 

Still, cool to see wacky stuff happen.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
"Be Like the Virus" would have been a bit much as a headline. But it was kind of my point here. 
We need an agile, anti-fragile, innovative economy. And for that, we can learn much from the evolutionary success of super-mutant COVID-19
https://t.co/Ru82iC6qlT

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Last chance for comments on the @wef's blockchain presidio principles before a May 5 deadline. This important values-defining document will be released at Consensus the following week.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jgarzik Maybe the best we can hope for is to build and deploy in time for the next pandemic.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Techemist @CT_Bergstrom Yes, to me the problem is the prevailing assumption that the data must be centrally stored when in fact, decentralized self-sovereign models are here and available. The conversation, at the corporate and nation-state level, is trapped in a 20th century mindset of IT silos.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Techemist OK. Read the rest of the thread, and then ping me. I wrote about this last week -- as per last tweet in the thread, essentially saying, yes, it's possible.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Of course, we need to listen to epidemiologists. And of course we should study and learn from success stories in Asian and elsewhere. But, as I wrote last week, let's also listen to the cryptographers. https://t.co/EuAqtIPbn8 8/8

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: So I, for one, think there has to be a happy medium in which decentralized cryptographic systems combine with some modest level of government oversight can be a solution to reopening the economy safely - safely for lives and safely for our freedom.  7/8

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: With globalization and free trade under threat, and populism on the rise, we were already living under political and economic conditions ripe for fascism and authoritarian socialism. Why give political thugs the tools and the excuse to take us further down that path? 6/8

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
But, to be clear, adopting the Asian model is an option that we cannot take lightly. We know from experience governments find it very hard to roll back such measures. 

5/8

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: And, needless to say, @CT_Bergstrom's points - retweeted  in the first part of this thread - are compelling. It's very easy to imagine a maelstrom of misinformation and false warnings leading to mistrust, complacency and inaction that render a voluntary model user. 4/8

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: But, sadly, @mattyglesias's observations about Asian countries' success are correct. The fact is that aggressive suppression works.  is it fact we're just incapable of admitting? 3/8 https://t.co/SfA6ecKn5h

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Having seen what the Patriot Act did to civil liberties, how it enabled Google-Facebook's Age of Surveillance Capitalism and turned the Internet into a tool of manipulation, we must hesitate to conclude that only a more authoritarian model of social control can beat COVID-19. 2/8

name: Michael J. Casey

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Yes, SK's contact tracing approach invades civil liberties in ways Americans won't (and shouldn't) abide. That's why new, privacy-protecting solutions (e.g. DP3T) are being developed and should be encouraged. (Why the backtracking, EU?) https://t.co/GfWvlen3dT ...

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
How did SK succeed? 

With 1) data! and 2) coherent, nationwide communication and implementation. 

That translated into:

1) Fast, massively scalable testing. (No excuse, other than woeful unpreparedness, for US not to have been as good.)

2) Contact tracing (thoughts below)...

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
NYC's international, transient community meant it was inherently vulnerable. But, damn it, we knew that would be the case!

Impossible not to conclude the response to the outbreak - first overseas, then domestically - was woefully slower and massively more inadequate in US.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
Is density a factor? A little, maybe.

US epicenter became NYC; Korea's: Daegu. (NYC 4 x size; 9 x dense). But countries similarly urbanized. 

Key difference: in SK, they more or less confined it to Daegu; Seoul was spared. Whereas In US it started with Seattle, weeks before NYC

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
The comparisons ring as a damning indictment of US preparedness and organizational capacity. 

Per capita, South Korea has 9% of US cases and 0.04% deaths. Note: 

SK is now easing lockdown.

tweet: Who decides who meets these criteria? Me. And, yes, my views on fair comment are inherently biased. But personal censorship is totally different from censorship by a platform manager. Choosing who I reward in my network is merely an execution of my own free speech rights. 6/7

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: ...when I see politically motivated people and institutions with large followings deliberately exploiting bots and blind fanatics to virally spread destructive disinformation, their countervailing opinions cease, in my mind, to be helpful. It's downright dangerous. 5/7

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: ...this crisis has led me to a tipping point. To get beyond it, we desperately need not only reliable information but also that its dissemination effectively evolves into knowledge. Of course we need a variety of views. So I still oppose social media de-platforming. But...4/7

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: A persons' network engagement - positive or negative - defines their power and influence. I used to believe feeding their engagement value was a lesser-evil price worth paying to sustain free speech. So, I kept an open door to all sorts of critics, trolls and nutters. But...3/7

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: I strongly believe in free speech and open debate. But I have finally come around to believing that the economics of Twitter's two-way engagement, unlike traditional one-way news flow, requires a new mindset.  2/7

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @dstadulis At this stage, it's not about morality. I too would prefer a system of non-intrusive government. I'm a believer in markets, and see a desperate need to reduce state-sponsored violence. BUT... right now, the power of government is wedge that can help us. Markets aren't enough.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @dstadulis Sorry. But in times like this, we can't rely on markets to solve all our resource needs. Precisely because of inefficiencies that offer trading opportunities, demand+supply won't adjust quickly enough. Traders will profit, yes, but hospital beds won't just materialize in a week

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @dstadulis And you think a lack of hospital beds needed in a week's time would be solved by some arbitrage trading strategy! Jesus Christ. This is how we got in this mess.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @dstadulis That assumes markets are totally efficient, which, as 2008 taught us, they definitely aren't. We live with inefficiencies in normal times because it's a lot better than a planned economy. But these are NOT normal times. We can't afford to wait for market distortions to play out

name: Michael J. Casey

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola I'm not sure it is, either. Not in its current form and not for this particular problem. But that's a different question from whether a large enough number of people will look to it as a  hedge and thus whether its price will rise.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola No. Not yet. And until a widely adopted alternative exists, USD surges, yields plunge and the global imbalances I wrote about in The Unfair Trade, worsen. It's why I think bitcoin rallies eventually - whether it's viable or not, the *idea* of an alternative underpins it.

name: Michael J. Casey

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola I think you're right from a structural economic perspective. But as I said, there are questions of trust and confidence -- itself a pandemic problem -- that come into play.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola But after 6 yrs in Argentina I do believe there's a wildcard here: what can start out as temporary price shocks can lead to lasting ones if trust in the institutional management of money breaks down. I'm relatively confident in the Fed, but very much not so in USG more broadly

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola "Weimar" was a convenient - yes, imperfect - way to encapsulate what I was asking: will price behavior be different this time? I think there are human behavioral factors here that haven't been modeled before. I don't think hyperinflation is the likely outcome.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola Yes. It creates reserves, shifts holdings from one class of asset to another. It is not helicopter money. I know this! But it does create distortions in the economy. And those distortions *might* play out differently this time due to different circumstances.

name: Michael J. Casey

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola @YangTerrence @novogratz @PeterMcCormack Oh my God. In that previous thread, to which you know I was referring here, you literally told me I know nothing "at all" about something I definitely do know something about. Try a little tiny bit of self reflection.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Frances_Coppola Oh, for God sake. It was unnecessarily harsh. I'm baffled that you can't see that. Tweets are not a place for nuance, sure. But in this case there's zero ambiguity in the words "At all."

name: Michael J. Casey

name: Michael J. Casey

name: Michael J. Casey

name: Michael J. Casey

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @kimdhamilton @jillruthcarlson @dgwbirch Ouch.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jillruthcarlson @dgwbirch So, in retrospect, maybe we'd have been better going for a different title, one that's not so easily misunderstood.  But it has been fun engaging in debates with the likes of Dave over this.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jillruthcarlson @dgwbirch But I now get that "truth" is a very sensitive word. Sometimes, in speeches, I try the old "truth is relative - truth is consensus" line on the audience, and it invariably prompts a visceral reaction.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jillruthcarlson @dgwbirch It's also a bit of a play on Yuval Harari's idea on how valuable it is that societies arrive at "truths" that are really just common agreements. In other words, it's about  consensus and, in this case, new mechanisms (blockchains) for arriving at it.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jillruthcarlson Suffice to say that @dgwbirch have gone round and round on this. I stand by the idea, explained in the book, that we're talking about the power of "shared truths," not absolute truths, that are fundamental to how society moves forward.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @JosephBWalton The difference, I think, is the question of the governance model for managing rights to the good in question.  A truly decentralized protocol is neither governance by state, nor by corporation. Is it "public," then? It's certainly not "private."

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Legit question. Mainstream media  is still grappling with 20th-century terminology, where public=government and private=everyone else. We must help the world understand that protocols run by open, decentralized communities don't fit into that simple dichotomy.
