tweet:
What's clear is that staff at big tech platforms who challenge their employers' practices deserve the public's support. It's also why pieces like @noamscheiber and @kateconger's are vital, shedding light on the workings of the most powerful private organizations in history

13/

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
As software eats the world, demand for tech labor will continue to rise. Question is whether, with their outsized salary-paying capacity and two decades of (mostly) worker loyalty, those talent shortages are enough to force Google to respond to workers' demands for integrity
12/

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
Either way, these dissident employees should be applauded for an undertaking of profound societal importance. While the cards might seem stacked against them, they have leverage in a way that we users/suppliers don't: their labor is in hot demand and short supply. 

11/

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
What to do? We need to support decentralized approaches to indexing the Internet's information such as @OpenIndexProto and approaches to data that work around the Internet platforms' information silos such as @streambedmedia 

10/

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
All of this is fueled by the end-game in Silicon Valley's 100x-return investment model, which demanded rapid growth at all costs - translated for public tech companies into shareholder demands for relentless quarterly growth in an age of zero interest rates. 

9/

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
As such, govts and other intelligence clients (such as those the Google employee dissidents are fighting against) will become an ever-larger source of funding for platforms like Google, all as AI starts to rapidly expand the possibilities of "surveillance as a service."  

8/

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
Also: While ads have until now been Google's dominant source of revenue, that will change as digital marketing and publishing models adjust to consumer backlashes and as an alternative monetization strategy tied to Google's giant data pool becomes increasingly attractive 

7/

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
Might we instead use our "supply-side" leverage - as providers of data on which Google depends - to demand change? Hardly. It would require huge coordination and a willingness among users who don't seem to care about privacy to give up on the convenience of network effects

6/

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
Since we're not its customers, we users can't exercise market power to force change. Google's all-powerful network effect in search, means that brand image is now less of a priority. "Don't be Evil" was once a de facto marketing message. Not anymore. 

5/

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
So without an ability to control the information we receive, and as we lose our own behavioral free will, how do we stop this capitalist version of Big Brother from destroying society itself? In that context, these activist employees seem like our last line of defense!

4/

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
Per @shoshanazuboff, the model is depleting our free will. We're not Google's or Facebook's customers. We're their "mines" (activity quarries from which they extract data as a resource) and a "product" they constantly evolve by directing us in ways that modify our behavior

3/

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
It starts with Google's status as the Internet's indexing system, deciding what information we get with a profit-seeking curation model driven by our behavioral data. Combined with similar models at Facebook & other platforms, it massively distorts how we process information

2/

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet:
.@kateconger and @noamscheiber's fine, thought-provoking essay on Google's harsh treatment of workplace dissent falls short in 1 way: it should have positioned the topic in the wider societal context of surveillance capitalism. My take in this thread:
1/

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @panekkkk Don't misread me: I think #DeFi is brilliant. It opens the door to exciting possibilities. But from where I sit, as the enthusiasm grows, there are too many cheerleaders ignoring systemic risks. I agree with you that this event is going to help focus attention. A good thing

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @panekkkk Of course it is. And, yes, in your, smart circles no one is talking about free lunches.  But the longing for a silver bullet (sorry, another hackneyed metaphor) is a real phenomenon in the general public, the people on whose naivete bubbles are built.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @panekkkk Agree. That's a huge acceleration in the iterative feedback loop of development. Compare to how long it took to recognize and respond to the root causes of the 2008 financial crisis.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @paulvigna @sytaylor Yep. The solution is always about trade-offs.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @paulvigna @musatheredguard @sytaylor Here, the Intersection of centralized finance and decentralized currencies makes things interesting. China's CBDC seems miles from BTC or ETH, but it'll unleash a global competitive battle for new finance models from which will arise hybrid solutions to your trust challenge, Paul

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @paulvigna @sytaylor Sure. But thinking about how you'd design a system that doesn't fall into that trap - one that's still "sufficiently" decentralized to fulfill the promise of low-friction credit but sufficiently robust to avoid systemic risk - is what's fascinating here.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @sytaylor @JamieJBartlett Yep. You could talk about this for a full week, I reckon, Simon. The rabbit hole this takes you down is a long and thought-provoking.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Great piece by @CoinDesk's new privacy reporter, @benjaminopowers. You'll see more articles on these "crypto-adjacent" topics herein: not directly about blockchains or cryptocurrencies but relevant to them and addressed thru the lens of decentralization https://t.co/hFUhxruk7o

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi @alexmagnusBTC @La__Cuen @cuysheffield Absolutely! Criticism is vital. Journalism can only thrive if it's open to it.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi @alexmagnusBTC @La__Cuen @cuysheffield The general public is woefully under-informed on these matters. But needs to be involved. And that, of course, is an argument for why we need quality, independent journalism to thrive in the crypto space.  (I really did wrap this up with a nice, self-serving bow, didn't I?) 😃

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi @alexmagnusBTC @La__Cuen @cuysheffield It's also why -- as we move into the era of CBDCs -- we need high-level, well-informed public debate and discussion on these systems are to develop and evolve. The hurly burly of Crypto Twitter won't cut it, I'm afraid.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi @alexmagnusBTC @La__Cuen @cuysheffield One reason I'm really interested to see how Bermuda grapples with these challenges. It has direct vested interests in both sides of the balance: big dependencies on heavily regulated financial institutions but also a citizenry  that's badly financially excluded.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi @alexmagnusBTC @La__Cuen @cuysheffield Same goes for KYC/AML regulations -- what priority to place on preventing "derisking" and enabling financial inclusion -- against protecting the system from capture by illicit finance? In my mind, regulators have been way too skewed to the latter on that one...

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi @alexmagnusBTC @La__Cuen @cuysheffield But, in his (partial) defense, it's hard for regulators (i.e. "system designers") to define those differences when it's not clear that they're job is to balance competing priorities.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi @alexmagnusBTC @La__Cuen @cuysheffield The controversy around Bloomberg was specifically that he attributed the crisis to the end of "redlining." There's a difference between outright discrimination and risk mitigation.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi @alexmagnusBTC @La__Cuen @cuysheffield To tie these 2 threads together, it's why I want a viable solution to the "flash loan" problem in crypto. I think the way BTC can be both a hodler's digital gold AND a force for financial inclusion is by making credit less costly - as low-friction (NOT no-friction) collateral

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi @alexmagnusBTC @La__Cuen @cuysheffield I'm not ready to say it can't, but we need to think about these overall systemic constraints before deciding on what BTC's true value prop is.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi @alexmagnusBTC @La__Cuen @cuysheffield Yep. To your point on a different thread: they're intermediaries whose "role" is to impose friction/extract costs so the "system" can pay for itself/be self-sustaining. It's an open question whether hodler-dominated bitcoin can achieve that in ways that make micropayments viable

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @alexmagnusBTC @La__Cuen @mayazi @cuysheffield Yes, for now, I agree that Lightning and other solutions could make BTC micropayments attractive in USD jurisdictions. But central banks eveywhere will be issuing digital currencies sooner than people think. If China's has sub-cent capability, you can bet that the Fed's will too

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @La__Cuen @mayazi Yes, but I'd describe that as an advtge stemming from the core censorship-resistant value prop of bitcoin - the things that make it non-state, cross-border, "global." My pt was to challenge @cuysheffield's idea that sub-cent TX, and not all that other stuff, would drive adoption

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @TorBair @mayazi Sure. So long as "collateral damage" (excuse pun) is minimized. Crypto is still a relatively small field of elites, so, yes, a deploy-fail-redploy approach is attractive. But I think we end up in same place. "The system" finds a way to impose costs. Circuit-breakers could be that

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @TorBair @mayazi Right. So the other outcome is that the system evolves to put a halt to the self-harming behavior - in this case, lending to short-sellers. Either way, it is the same outcome: borrowing becomes impossibly expensive. Crypto lending as a project fails.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jeffscottward It does, but the players in a box spread trade are making risk assessments of the counterparty risks of all the other players and pricing the deal accordingly. In #DeFi participants areblind to the counterparty. Risk is supposed to be covered purely by collateral.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: So, how do we protect this system from such exploits and enable it to develop in a way that is affordable for users? @mayazi has some useful thoughts. Circuit-breakers?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: How does this community respond? By jacking up interest rates. Rates will skyrocket to impose the necessary cost on the short-seller. That will be a pity, because crypto lending is an exciting new field that poses real opportunities for reduced friction and more access to finance

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Someone is bearing the risk/cost here. And it seems to be that it's the entire community of ETH hodlers who will quite quickly wake up to the fact that a free short-selling system has just emerged to relentlessly drive down the price. #flashcrash

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Only catching up on this "flash loan" thing now and it's making my head explode. Yes, pure genius. But I'm alarmed at all the numskulls who think this is a "democratizing of finance" There is no free lunch, folks, only loopholes yet to be closed... https://t.co/VbPU8BkwlS

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi If sub-cent TX is the only thing giving bitcoin an edge over fiat - and not censorship-resistance, pseudonymity etc. - then that competitive advantage won't last. It will be trivial for China to add this feature to the digital yuan, no?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mattocko Some bona fide experts are saying similar things, btw. John Nicholls, HKU key player in identifying the SARS coronavirus in 2003, had this to say: https://t.co/mu52r8BwlN

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mattocko Not saying this isn't a crisis. Rate of infection is scarily fast. But don't see how higher reported case rate than death rate is bad news. Flu has very, very wide infection rates each yr; we don't freak out because fatality rate is low. Why not welcome lower fatality rate news

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mattocko Perhaps over-reaction - mass quarantines based on inflated estimates of fatality rate - contributes. For the record, I threw "dying slower" in there to ack that it's too early to say for sure that vast majority will survive, but it's very reasonable to speculate that's the case.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mattocko So, you'd argue that they are suppressing an 8-fold increase in deaths, but admitting to a 10-fold increase in cases? Sorry dude, but that's sounds like a nuttily elaborate conspiracy. China's big on cover-ups, yes. But there is a more reasonable explanation: poor methodology

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mattocko We all knew China was underreporting. Not necessarily a conspiracy - simply because measurement methodologies were inadequate. Now, doctor discretion gets us closer to real number. What do we see? So far, many more are surviving (or maybe dying slower?) than thought.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mattocko Hmmm. Not doing "calm porn" or downplaying need for extreme vigilance, but evidence of underreporting can be good news: lower fatality rate. Total deaths were surely much more accurate than total case numbers initially; as latter improves, metrics on threat to human life lessen

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @iang_fc @paulvigna So depressing. I think remember that paper, Ian. It was excellent.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @paulvigna Definitely shouldn't be downplayed. Not talking about it is the worst way to deal with it. As I said, it proves we need regulation, but also education on how to identify these scams and avoid them.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jgharris7 @el33th4xor You're not a multinational moving billions of dollars in money and goods between non-trusting entities.  You can't extrapolate from a low-risk retail customer experience with EZ-Pass into some broad statement about how international business works.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Numbers like this expose the need for education and, unavoidably, regulation. From what I hear, many mainstream companies working with crypto and blockchain aren't publicly talking about it for fear of being associated with what the general public assumes is scam tech. Sad

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @lone_alphie Huh? I totally agree trust minimization is key.  In fact, it's how you get to programmability of money. The trust boundaries in IOU-based banking make it impossible to create atomic swaps, decentralized escrow, on-chain collateral and all else that programmability promises.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @pascalbouvier Maybe we think of money here -- digital bearer instruments -- as the base government layer, the piece that needs to work in a reliable, constraining way, enabling all the other rich programmability to occur in applications that use that core functionality. 2/2

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @pascalbouvier Don't disagree. But maybe this equates with "dumb" governance idea at the Internet's base TCP/IP layer. Its limitation was deliberate, ensuring security in core packet-switching function, but also enabling (and encouraging) innovation up the stack in middleware & app layers 1/2

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @jgharris7 I'm sure you'll disagree, but I personally don't think it's possible to achieve programmability with anything short of a digital bearer instrument. The trust boundaries within the existing financial system's IOU-based model creates too much friction.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @bristolzero @jp_koning The open question is how much cannibalization of banks' incumbent businesses do these new models represent (whether open APIs or distributed ledger-based digital currencies - the question is the same). And how much of that they can tolerate?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: I agree with Gun. It's the programmability aspect of these new versions of money and finance that will eventually make them so disruptive. When money is programmable, the analog system can't compete. Wall Street does seem blindsided. So too USG. Dollar's dominance is at stake.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Important PSA from the @CoinDesk editorial team: Don’t Fall for It: Scammers Are Impersonating CoinDesk Staff on Social Media https://t.co/NtiplvJX1S

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @TheStalwart @neelkashkari @Aarondklein Why does it matter? Because programmability radically changes the nature of each business transaction. The money itself now contains powerful informational value. It means verification happens instantly. This leads to radical, cross-entity automation - smart supply chains etc 2/2

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @TheStalwart @neelkashkari @Aarondklein Also key: "programmable money" is only possible with digital bearer instruments. Bank IOUs cannot be inserted into a program as a trusted, autonomous piece of information in the way that digital currencies can. This is why China's initiative is a major challenge to the US.  1/2

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi @StenderWorld @nytimes @shoshanazuboff True. That's an important nuance. Laws are intended to modify behavior but are ostensibly meant to be transparently established and executed, based on consensus, and aimed at net-positive social benefit. Platform algorithms can claim to have those qualities.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @StenderWorld @mayazi @nytimes Yep. We need to ask, what is the meta-intent, the real purpose, of privacy-invading data extraction? To me, the answer has to be: behavior modification. Eventually tracking tends toward diminished human agency at scale. This is @shoshanazuboff's case in Surveillance Capitalism.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @mayazi @nytimes So we surrender? What sort of a society/culture do we create in a world of zero privacy? What does it mean to be an individual? Is there such thing as free will?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @La__Cuen Context for why Swiss bankers interested in alternative money: Switzerland has been screwed by a double-whammy this past decade: euro zone's low interest rates and OECD's tougher standards on bank secrecy. Low rates and fear of euro crisis sent money flooding into francs... 1/2

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @balajis Civility norms evolved over time. In The Social Organism, @revilopark and I explored how online culture is also evolving. Question is, will it go in that direction? Evolution is neither good nor bad. Memes, like genes, are selfish, as Dawkins posited. The fittest survive.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Distressed debt can be a profitable investment, of course. But it requires a functioning court system that respects foreign investors' property rights. Good luck with that in China.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @BryanFJacoutot That feels like whataboutism. How the discussion is framed here is irrelevant. Even if I conceded that the human cause of climate change is an unresolved theory, stories that arsonists started the Aussie fires are still meaningless to that debate.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @BryanFJacoutot Point. Missed.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: Climate change'e role is about the drought conditions that made the fires spread so far, fast and virulently. It's irrelevant whether arsonists started them, unless you think 10s of 1000s of arsonists are repeatedly putting themselves in danger and relighting fires every day 2/2

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @FrancoMunizAR @santisiri There's still human programming setting the priorities of the algorithm. What AI does is remove the emotional attachment between the human making the (now algorithmically implemented) kill order and the victim. That's what scares me. It extracts the "cost" from the decision.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @FrancoMunizAR @santisiri Significa, también, que hemos permitido más que una oportunidad de rentabilidad para esa compañía - es una forma de poder divino.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @FrancoMunizAR @santisiri El problema no es el bias ni la exactitud de los drones v los humanos. Es que los humanos están separadas de la decisión. Sin responsabilidad humana de la juicios sobre quién muera y quien no, que tipo de sociedad tenemos?

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Steve_Lockstep @dgwbirch @fredwilson @Apple Eventually, yes. But we're not there yet. We need much more than E2E encryption. Firms must disavow data extraction/behavior modification. The right regulation will incentivize early profit-seekers to differentiate around hardcore privacy. Later, it's commoditized - or so I hope.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @iang_fc @dgwbirch That piece was a valuable resource for @paulvigna and me when we detailed the rise and fall of DigiCash in our book, The Age of Cryptocurrency. Thanks @iang_fc!

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Steve_Lockstep @dgwbirch @fredwilson ...Yes, regulation is key - a catalyst for new business models. But with the right technologies (e.g., ZKP solutions for identity and compliance), and with organizing systems that boost user-producer bargaining power, I think privacy-as-service has a future.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @Steve_Lockstep @dgwbirch @fredwilson I like to think a new breed of provider will emerge, gaining market share by touting privacy as a feature. It will require service-based businesses replacing surveillance capitalism's data extraction model and greater consumer consciousness...

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @ZoeJDolan @fredwilson I especially like the insight on cryptography and bitcoin. It's a constructive way to think about the contribution the latter - not as a game-changer for money per se (though it can yet still be that) but as the catalyst for an explosion of cryptographic invention.

name: Michael J. Casey
tweet: @ZoeJDolan @fredwilson Yep, Fred has a knack for distilling seemingly disparate events into coherent trends and then identifying the most salient issues and questions they raise.
